root.publications: Baker, Brett. 2004. Stem Forms and Paradigm Reshaping in Gunwinyguan. In Claire Bowern & Harold Koch (eds.), Australian Languages: The classification and comparative method, vol. 249, 314-340. Amsterdam: John Benjamins.

child.publications: Baker, Brett. 2004. Stem Forms and Paradigm Reshaping in Gunwinyguan. In Claire Bowern & Harold Koch (eds.), Australian Languages: The classification and comparative method, vol. 249, 314-340. Amsterdam: John Benjamins.

Baker, Brett. 2004. Stem Forms and Paradigm Reshaping in Gunwinyguan. In Claire Bowern & Harold Koch (eds.), Australian Languages: The classification and comparative method, vol. 249, 314-340. Amsterdam: John Benjamins.

Baker, Brett. 2004. Stem Forms and Paradigm Reshaping in Gunwinyguan. In Claire Bowern & Harold Koch (eds.), Australian Languages: The classification and comparative method, vol. 249, 314-340. Amsterdam: John Benjamins.

child.pub-comments: "My primary focus in what follows is on Ngalakgan and Rembarrnga. I show that there is evidecne of systematic innovation in verb inflection morphology, and they may therefore be subgrouped together. I will call this subgroup 'Jala' (from the word for 'mouth' in Rembarrnga and Ngalakgan)" (Baker 2004: 313). "I hope that I have shown conclusively that Ngalakgan and Rembarrnga are not only closely related, but share a number of systematic correspondences not found in other languages of the GN [Gunwinyguan] family. These correspondences indicate a period of independent innovation in their immediate ancestor, which is reflected in each daughter language. Similiarly, there are sets of correspondences in Ngandi and Wubuy which indicate that these two languages also should be considered to derive from a single ancestor. Apart from these two subgroups, it is difficult to show correspondences of the same order between any other two (groups of) GN languages, leaving the question of the internal break-up pf GN as yet unresolved" (Baker 2004: 340).

child.pub-comments: "I hope that I have shown conclusively that Ngalakgan and Rembarrnga are not only closely related, but share a number of systematic correspondences not found in other languages of the GN [Gunwinyguan] family. These correspondences indicate a period of independent innovation in their immediate ancestor, which is reflected in each daughter language. Similiarly, there are sets of correspondences in Ngandi and Wubuy which indicate that these two languages also should be considered to derive from a single ancestor. Apart from these two subgroups, it is difficult to show correspondences of the same order between any other two (groups of) GN languages, leaving the question of the internal break-up of GN as yet unresolved" (Baker 2004: 340).

root.pub-comments: This subgrouping of Gunwinyguan does not include all Gunwinyguan languages, but only those that the author studied in this chapter. He also felt that the other Gunwinyguan languages could not be conclusively classified into subgroups of Gunwinyguan yet for lack of evidence. "I hope that I have shown conclusively that Ngalakgan and Rembarrnga are not only closely related, but share a number of systematic correspondences not found in other languages of the GN [Gunwinyguan] family. These correspondences indicate a period of independent innovation in their immediate ancestor, which is reflected in each daughter language. Similiarly, there are sets of correspondences in Ngandi and Wubuy which indicate that these two languages also should be considered to derive from a single ancestor. Apart from these two subgroups, it is difficult to show correspondences of the same order between any other two (groups of) GN languages, leaving the question of the internal break-up of GN as yet unresolved" (Baker 2004: 340).
